script-selector-help: The desired shell script language to use to display the shell script.
kubectl-k8s-flavor-help: The Kubernetes cluster provider type where the Oracle Fusion Middleware domain will be deployed.
kubectl-exe-file-path-help: The full path to the Kubernetes kubectl client executable that is compatible with the target Kubernetes cluster.
kubectl-config-file-help: The Kubernetes client configuration file(s) to use.  Leave this empty to use the default location.
kubectl-config-context-help: The Kubernetes config file context name for the cluster to which you want to connect.  The default is to use whatever the current context is, if any.
kubectl-add-row-icon-text: Add Extra Kubernetes Client Path Directory
kubectl-choose-path-icon-text: Choose Extra Kubernetes Client Path Directory
kubectl-delete-row-icon-text: Remove Extra Kubernetes Client Path Directory
kubectl-helm-exe-file-path-help: The full path to the Helm executable that is used to install the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator and some ingress controllers in your Kubernetes cluster.
kubectl-list-completeInstructions: Follow the instructions in the {{link}} to complete the configuration.
kubectl-list-eksTitle: Amazon Web Services (AWS) -- Elastic Container Service for Kubernetes (EKS)
kubectl-list-install: Install kubectl using the instructions from {{link}}.
kubectl-list-installNoVerify: Install kubectl using the instructions from {{link}}. Please skip the "Verifying kubectl configuration" section.
kubectl-list-kindClusterAccess: Creating a kind cluster should automatically modify your kubectl configuration to allow access to the cluster.  See the {{link}} for more information.
kubectl-list-okeTitle: Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) -- Oracle Container Engine for Kubernetes (OKE)
kubectl-list-verifyInstall: Open a command line and run {{command}} to verify the installation before proceeding.
kubectl-list-versionSkew: When installing kubectl, please install a version that is compatible with the target Kubernetes cluster. Please refer to the {{link}} for more information.
kubectl-list-extraPathDirectories: On MacOS, add the directory where the {{executable}} executable is installed to the Extra Kubernetes Client Path Directories list.
kubectl-list-eks-extraPathDirectories: On MacOS, add the directory where the either the {{executable1}} or the {{executable2}} executable is installed to the Extra Kubernetes Client Path Directories list.
kubectl-hints-verifyKubectlConnectivity: Verify Kubernetes Client Connectivity to Cluster
kubectl-helper-kubectl-exe-invalid-error: Unable to verify Kubernetes client connectivity because the Kubernetes client executable is invalid: {{error}}.
kubectl-helper-project-not-saved-error-p: Unable to verify Kubernetes client connectivity because project save failed
kubectl-helper-set-context-error-message: Unable to verify Kubernetes client connectivity because setting the cluster context failed: {{error}}.
kubectl-helper-verify-connect-success-me: Kubernetes client (version {{clientVersion}}) successfully connected to the Kubernetes cluster (version {{serverVersion}}).
kubectl-helper-verify-connect-failed-err: Failed to verify Kubernetes client connectivity: {{error}}.
kubectl-helper-verify-connect-catch-all-: Failed to verify Kubernetes client connectivity due to an unexpected error: {{error}}.
project-settings-domain-location-title: Target Oracle Fusion Middleware Domain Location
project-settings-domain-location-questio: Where would you like the target Oracle Fusion Middleware domain to live?
project-settings-domain-location-help: Where and when the Oracle Fusion Middleware domain will be created.
project-settings-domain-location-mii-lab: Created in the container from the model in the image
project-settings-domain-location-dii-lab: Created as part of the image
project-settings-domain-location-pv-labe: Externally created in a Kubernetes persistent volume
project-settings-domain-location-mii-mes: The WebLogic Kubernetes Operator creates the domain in the container used to represent the Administration Server.
project-settings-domain-location-dii-mes: The WebLogic Image Tool creates the domain inside the image during the image creation process.
project-settings-domain-location-pv-mess: The target domain must already exist in a Kubernetes Persistent Volume that is accessible to the target Kubernetes cluster. Because no new domain is being created, there is no need to have a model. There is no need to create a new image because the standard Oracle Fusion Middleware images in the Oracle Container Registry can be used directly.
project-settings-wdt-target-type-questio: What type of Kubernetes cluster would you like to target?
project-settings-wdt-target-type-help: Select the target type to use for preparing the model for the target Kubernetes environment.
project-settings-wdt-target-type-answer-: When deploying a domain to Kubernetes using either a domain in the image or a model in the image, the WebLogic Deploy Tooling needs to know what type of Kubernetes environment you plan to use.
project-settings-image-builder-type-ques: Which program do you want to use for building the new image and pushing it to an image registry?
project-settings-image-builder-type-help: Choose the program that you want to use to build images and push them to an image registry.
project-settings-image-builder-type-answ: You have chosen to use {{imageBuilderType}} to build your new image and push it to an image registry.
project-settings-directory-locations-que: Which Java and Oracle installations would you like to use?
project-settings-java-home-help: The JAVA_HOME directory, which is typically the directory where the JDK is installed.
project-settings-oracle-home-help: The directory containing the Oracle Fusion Middleware installation to use.
project-settings-directory-locations-ans: The Java and Oracle Home directories will be used when running the WebLogic Deploy Tooling and WebLogic Image Tool.
project-settings-build-tool-type-questio: What tool do you want to use to work with container images?
project-settings-build-tool-type-help: The software package to use to build, push, and pull images.
project-settings-build-tool-help: The path to the executable to use to build, push, and pull images.
project-settings-build-tool-type-answer-: The selected tool will be used to build the target image, as well as logging in, pushing, and pulling images to and from any image registries.
project-settings-credential-store-policy: How should the project's credentials be stored for this project?
Specifies if and how credentials will be stored for the project.
project-settings-credential-store-native: Store in Native OS Credential Store
project-settings-credential-store-policy: The Credential Store Policy controls how credentials are handled when the project is saved and loaded.  The options are to store them in the machine's native credential store, store them in the project file encrypted with a passphrase, or not store them at all.
user-settings-dialog-https-proxy-url-hel: The proxy server URL to use for all outbound HTTPS requests.
user-settings-dialog-bypass-proxy-hosts-: The list of hostnames or patterns to use to set the NO_PROXY environment variable.  Please see NO_PROXY documentation for legal values.
user-settings-dialog-console-level-help: The log level to use to filter output to the console.
user-settings-dialog-file-level-help: The log level to use to filter output to the log file.
user-settings-dialog-file-dir-help: The directory to use for writing the application log files.
user-settings-dialog-quickstart-section-: WebLogic Kubernetes Toolkit UI Introduction Configuration
user-settings-dialog-quickstart-skip-hel: Whether or not to skip showing the WebLogic Kubernetes Toolkit UI Introduction at application startup.
image-design-title: Create the Image for the WebLogic Domain
image-design-image-tag-help: The tag to use to identify the new (or existing) image containing the Oracle Fusion Middleware installation to run the domain.
image-design-image-registry-address-help: The image registry hostname and port to use to log in to the registry, if required. This field's value is parsed from the Image Tag field and an empty value assumes Docker Hub is the registry being used.
image-design-create-image-help: Whether you want to create a new Oracle Fusion Middleware image or use an existing image, such as one of the standard images in the Oracle Container Registry.
image-design-image-registry-push-require: Whether you want to specify authentication credentials for pushing the new image to the registry.
image-design-image-registry-push-usernam: The image registry user name to use to log in to the registry prior to pushing the image.
image-design-image-registry-push-passwor: The image registry password to use to log in to the registry prior to pushing the image.
image-design-use-custom-base-image-help: Whether to use a custom base image to create the new image.
image-design-custom-base-image-help: The custom base image to use to build the new image.
image-design-custom-base-image-registry-: The base image's registry hostname and port to use to log in to the registry, if required. This field's value is parsed from the Custom Base Image to Use field and an empty value assumes Docker Hub is the registry being used.
image-design-base-image-use-authenticati: Custom Base Image Pull Requires Login
Whether pulling the custom base image requires logging in to the image registry.
image-design-base-image-pull-username-he: The user name to use to pull the custom base image.
image-design-base-image-pull-password-he: The password to use to pull the custom base image.
image-design-jdk-installer-help: The full path to the Linux JDK installer to use for Oracle Fusion Middleware.
image-design-jdk-installer-version-help: The JDK version number to use in the WebLogic Image Tool cache.
image-design-fmw-installer-label: Oracle Fusion Middleware Installer to Use
image-design-fmw-installer-help: The full path to the Oracle Fusion Middleware installer to use.
image-design-fmw-installer-type-help: The type of Oracle Fusion Middleware installer provided.
image-design-fmw-installer-type-fmw-labe: Oracle WebLogic Server for Fusion Middleware (JRF)
image-design-fmw-installer-type-soa_osb-: Oracle SOA Suite with Oracle Service Bus
image-design-fmw-installer-version-help: The Oracle Fusion Middleware version to use in the WebLogic Image Tool cache.
image-design-use-wdt-installer-label: Download and Use Latest WebLogic Deploy Tooling Installer
image-design-use-wdt-installer-help: Whether to download the latest WebLogic Deploy Tooling installer to use.
image-design-wdt-installer-label: WebLogic Deploy Tooling Installer to Use
image-design-wdt-installer-help: The full path to the WebLogic Deploy Tooling installer to use.
image-design-wdt-installer-version-help: The WebLogic Deploy Tooling version number to use in the WebLogic Image Tool cache.
image-design-apply-patches-help: Whether to apply patches to the Oracle Home after installation.
image-design-support-username-help: The Oracle Support user name to use to download patches.
image-design-support-password-help: The Oracle Support password to use to download patches.
image-design-psu-rec-help: Apply the latest PSU with or without other recommended patches.
image-design-patches-help: The list of one-off patches to apply.
image-design-domain-type-help: Specifies the type of Oracle Fusion Middleware domain to be created.
image-design-files-owner-help: The OS user to create inside the new image.  This user will own all installation files and directories, and run all installers inside the new image.
image-design-files-group-help: The OS group to create inside the new image.  This group will own all installation files and directories, and to run installers inside the new image.
image-design-always-pull-base-image-help: Always attempt to pull a newer version of base images during the build.
image-design-build-network-name-help: The network name to use when building the image.
image-design-extend-image-build-help: Whether to specify additional build commands to run.
image-design-additional-build-commands-f: The file containing additional image build commands.
image-design-additional-build-files-help: Files that are copied into the image build context for use by the Additional Build Commands File.
image-design-wdt-domain-home-help: The full path to the domain home directory inside the image.
image-design-wdt-model-home-help: The full path to the model home directory inside the image.
wko-design-k8s-namespace-help: The Kubernetes namespace into which the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator should be installed.
wko-design-k8s-service-account-help: The name of the Kubernetes service account in the operator's namespace that the operator will use to make requests to the Kubernetes API server.
wko-design-wko-deploy-name-label: Helm Release Name to Use for Operator Installation
wko-design-wko-deploy-name-help: The Helm release name used to install the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator.
wko-design-image-tag-help: The WebLogic Kubernetes Operator image to install.
wko-design-image-pull-policy-help: The policy that controls how often the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator image is pulled to the Kubernetes nodes.
wko-design-image-pull-requires-authentic: Specifies whether or not pulling the specified WebLogic Kubernetes Operator image requires authentication.
wko-design-use-existing-secret-help: Specifies whether to use an existing Kubernetes image pull secret.
wko-design-image-pull-secret-name-help: The name of the Kubernetes image pull secret to use to pull the specified image.
wko-design-image-registry-address-help: The hostname (and port) to use in creating the Kubernetes image pull secret, the value of which is extracted from the image tag.
wko-design-image-registry-username-help: The user name to use in creating the Kubernetes image pull secret.
wko-design-image-registry-email-help: The email address to use in creating the Kubernetes image pull secret.
wko-design-image-registry-password-help: The password to use in creating the Kubernetes image pull secret.
wko-design-k8s-namespace-selection-strat: Specifies how the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator will select the set of namespaces that it will manage.
wko-design-k8s-namespace-selection-list-: Namespace {{namespace}} in field Kubernetes Namespaces to Manage
The set of Kubernetes namespaces that the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator will manage.
wko-design-k8s-namespace-selection-selec: The label selector used to match the list of Kubernetes namespaces that the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator will manage.
wko-design-k8s-namespace-selection-regex: The regular expression used to match the list of Kubernetes namespaces that the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator will manage.
wko-design-k8s-role-binding-help: Specifies whether the roles necessary for the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator to manage domains will be granted using a ClusterRoleBinding rather than using RoleBindings in each managed namespace.
wko-design-external-rest-expose-help: Specifies whether the the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator's REST interface is exposed outside of the Kubernetes cluster on the port specified by the 'External REST HTTPS Port' field value.
wko-design-external-rest-port-help: Specifies the node port that should be allocated for the external WebLogic Kubernetes Operator REST API interface.
wko-design-external-rest-secret-label: External REST API Identity Secret Name
wko-design-external-rest-secret-help: The name of the Secret used to store the certificate and private key to use for the external operator REST HTTPS interface. The Secret has to be created in the same namespace of the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator.
wko-design-3rd-party-elk-enabled-help: Specifies whether or not ELK integration for the domain is enabled.
wko-design-3rd-party-logstash-image-help: Specifies the container image containing the version of Logstash to use.
wko-design-3rd-party-elastic-host-help: Specifies the hostname of where Elasticsearch is running.
wko-design-3rd-party-elastic-port-help: Specifies the port number of where Elasticsearch is running.
wko-design-logging-level-help: Specifies the Java logging level for the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator.
wko-design-logging-file-size-limit-help: Specifies the maximum size in bytes of a single log file in the container's /logs/ directory.
wko-design-logging-file-count-limit-help: Specifies the maximum number of log files to retain in the container's /logs/ directory.
wko-design-get-operator-status-set-conte: Failed to set kubectl context in get-operator-status {{error}}
wko-design-get-operator-log-set-context-: Failed to set kubectl context in get-operator-log {{error}}
domain-design-uid-help: An identification for the domain which is unique in the Kubernetes cluster.
domain-design-namespace-help: The Kubernetes namespace for the domain.
domain-design-domain-home-help: The path to the domain home in the container.  Leave the value empty to use the default value, which varies by target domain location.
domain-design-domain-home-readonly-help: This field is set by the Domain Home Path field on the Image page so go there to change its value.
domain-design-wls-credential-help: The name of the Kubernetes secret which holds the credentials for a user with administrative privileges.
domain-design-wls-credential-username-he: The name of the WebLogic user with administrative privileges.
domain-design-wls-credential-password-he: The password of the WebLogic user with administrative privileges.
domain-design-pv-volume-name-help: The name to use for the persistent volume in the domain resource specification.
domain-design-pv-volume-mount-path-help: The path in the container where the persistent volume should be mounted.
domain-design-pv-volume-claim-name-help: The name of the persistent volume claim to associate with the persistent volume.
domain-design-pv-volume-log-home-enabled: Whether or not to write the WebLogic Server log files to a location outside the domain home.
domain-design-pv-volume-log-home-help: The path to use to write the WebLogic Server log files.
domain-design-image-title: Image to Use for the Domain
domain-design-image-tag-help: The tag of the image to use for the domain.  This field is set by the Image Tag field on the Image page so go there to change its value, if needed.
domain-design-image-registry-address-hel: The image registry hostname and port to use to log in to the registry, if required.  This field's value is parsed from the Image Tag field and an empty value assumes Docker Hub is the registry being used.
domain-design-image-pull-policy-help: When to pull the domain's image from the image registry.
domain-design-image-registry-pull-requir: Whether you want to specify authentication credentials for pulling the image from the registry.
domain-design-image-registry-use-existin: Whether you want to use an existing image pull secret or create a new one.
domain-design-image-registry-pull-secret: The name of the Kubernetes secret to use as the image pull secret.
domain-design-image-registry-pull-userna: The image registry user name to use to log in to the registry prior to pull the image.
domain-design-image-registry-pull-passwo: The image registry password to use to log in to the registry prior to pull the image.
domain-design-image-registry-pull-email-: The image registry user's email address used to create the Kubernetes image pull secret.
domain-design-no-clusters-message: No clusters found for this domain. If your project has a model that defines clusters, please run Prepare Model to populate the clusters tables.
domain-design-domain-status-unknown: Unknown - Cannot determine the domain status now - check back later
domain-design-domain-status-complete: Complete - Domain is deployed and all servers are up and running
domain-design-domain-status-failed: Failed - Domain failed to deploy. Reason: {{reason}}
domain-design-domain-status-available: Available - Domain is deployed and some servers are up and running but the domain has not reaching the replicas count goal yet. Reason: {{reason}}
domain-design-domain-status-available-sh: Shutdown - Domain is deployed but all servers are down
domain-design-domain-status-comingup: Unknown - Domain is deployed, waiting for the operator to process the domain. It may take several minutes and longer for JRF domain, please check back later.
domain-design-domain-status-progressing: Progressing - Domain is being deployed or servers just starting up. Reason: {{reason}}
domain-design-cluster-name-help: The cluster name in the domain for which to enter settings.
domain-design-cluster-replicas-help: The number of managed servers to start for the cluster.
domain-design-cluster-min-heap-help: The minimum heap size for each server in the cluster, specified in bytes (may include a k, m, g suffix).
domain-design-cluster-max-heap-help: The maximum heap size for each server in the cluster, specified in bytes (may include a k, m, g suffix).
domain-design-cluster-cpu-request-help: The number of Kubernetes CPU units to request for each managed server.
domain-design-cluster-cpu-limit-help: The maximum amount of Kubernetes CPU units a managed server is allowed to use.
domain-design-cluster-memory-request-hel: The amount of memory to request for each managed server container. Memory is specified in bytes but the number may be qualified with the following Kubernetes-defined suffixes: K, Ki, M, Mi, G, Gi, T, Ti, P, Pi, E, Ei.
domain-design-cluster-memory-limit-help: The maximum amount of memory a managed server container is allowed to use. Memory is specified in bytes but the number may be qualified with the following Kubernetes-defined suffixes: K, Ki, M, Mi, G, Gi, T, Ti, P, Pi, E, Ei.
domain-design-cluster-debug-stdout-label: Disable debug logging to standard out
domain-design-cluster-debug-stdout-help: Prevent debug messages from being written to the server's standard output stream.
domain-design-cluster-disable-fan-label: Disable Oracle JDBC Support for FAN Events
domain-design-cluster-disable-fan-help: Only required for WebLogic Server version 12.2.1.3.0.
domain-design-cluster-use-urandom-help: Sets the random number generator to use /dev/urandom, which typically speeds up random number generation in containers in exchange for a slightly less random number.
domain-design-cluster-additional-java-op: A list of additional Java runtime options, separated by spaces, tabs, or commas.
domain-design-get-domain-status-set-cont: Failure to set kubectl context in get domain status {{error}}
domain-design-configmap-help: The name of the Kubernetes ConfigMap that holds the model variable overrides.
domain-design-encryption-secret-help: The name of the Kubernetes secret which holds the password used to encrypt the domain.
domain-design-encryption-value-help: The password used to encrypt the domain.
domain-design-introspector-job-active-de: The WebLogic Kubernetes Operator introspection job timeout value, measured in seconds.  The default value is 120 seconds, if not specified
domain-design-replicas-help: The number of managed servers to start for each cluster in the domain that lacks its own replicas setting.
domain-design-cpu-request-help: The number of Kubernetes CPU units to request for each WebLogic Server container.
domain-design-cpu-limit-help: The maximum amount of Kubernetes CPU units a WebLogic Server container is allowed to use.
domain-design-memory-request-help: The amount of memory to request for each WebLogic Server container. Memory is specified in bytes but the number may be qualified with the following Kubernetes-defined suffixes: K, Ki, M, Mi, G, Gi, T, Ti, P, Pi, E, Ei.
domain-design-memory-limit-help: The maximum amount of memory a WebLogic Server container is allowed to use. Memory is specified in bytes but the number may be qualified with the following Kubernetes-defined suffixes: K, Ki, M, Mi, G, Gi, T, Ti, P, Pi, E, Ei.
domain-design-debug-stdout-label: Disable Debug Logging to Standard Out
domain-design-debug-stdout-help: Prevent debug messages from being written to the server's standard output stream.
domain-design-disable-fan-label: Disable Oracle JDBC Support for FAN Events
domain-design-disable-fan-help: Only required for WebLogic Server version 12.2.1.3.0.
domain-design-use-urandom-help: Sets the random number generator to use /dev/urandom, which typically speeds up random number generation in containers in exchange for a slightly less random number.
domain-design-min-heap-help: The default minimum heap size for each server in the domain, specified in bytes (may include a k, m, g suffix).
domain-design-max-heap-help: The default maximum heap size for each server in the domain, specified in bytes (may include a k, m, g suffix).
domain-design-additional-java-options-he: A list of additional Java runtime options, separated by spaces, tabs, or commas.
domain-design-secrets-cell-field-name: Secrets table {{name}} field at row {{position}} with UID {{uid}}
ingress-page-hints-updateRouting: Update ingress routes to the domain in existing Ingress Controller
ingress-design-title: Configure Ingress for the Operator Domain
ingress-design-ingress-provider-help: The type of ingress controller to use.
ingress-design-install-ingress-controlle: Whether to install the selected ingress controller.
ingress-design-ingress-name-help: The Helm release name used to install the ingress controller.
ingress-design-ingress-namespace-help: The Kubernetes namespace to use for the ingress controller.
ingress-design-voyager-provider-help: The Kubernetes cluster provider type to use for Voyager.
ingress-design-specify-docker-registry-s: Whether to use a Docker Hub credential secret to pull the ingress controller image.  This is helpful if you encounter a Docker Hub pull limit exceeded error.
ingress-design-ingress-docker-reg-secret: The Kubernetes secret name to use when pulling images from Docker Hub. Note that the secret must exist in the same namespace as the ingress controller.
ingress-design-create-docker-registry-se: Whether to create a new Docker Hub credential secret or use an existing secret.
ingress-design-ingress-docker-reg-secret: The user name used to log in to Docker Hub.
The password used to log in to Docker Hub.
The email address of the user logging in to Docker Hub.
ingress-design-ingress-route-targetservi: The target service namespace value points to the namespace where the domain is running.
ingress-design-ingress-route-name-help: The name to be used for creating this ingress route.
ingress-design-ingress-route-virtualhost: The virtual host name is used as the host routing rule for this ingress route.
ingress-design-ingress-route-targetservi: The target service is the where this ingress route will send the request to the backend Kubernetes service address.
ingress-design-ingress-route-targetport-: The target port is the where this ingress route will send the request to the backend Kubernetes service port.
ingress-design-ingress-route-path-help: The URL path routing rule for this ingress route.
ingress-design-ingress-route-annotation-: The name of the annotation used for this ingress route.
The value for the annotation used for this ingress route.
ingress-design-specify-tls-secret-help: To secure traffic to the ingress controller with TLS, specify the secret that contains the TLS private key and certificate. The Ingress resource only supports a single TLS port, 443, and assumes TLS termination at the ingress (traffic between the ingress and the service and its pods is in clear text).
ingress-design-tls-secret-name-help: The name of the TLS secret to use if the ingress route has TLS Enabled checked. The TLS secret must contain keys named tls.crt and tls.key that contain the certificate and private key to use and, must be in the same namespace as the WebLogic domain.
ingress-design-create-tls-secret-help: Whether to create a new or use an existing TLS secret for the ingress route.
ingress-design-ingress-tlscertfile-help: The file containing the TLS certificate to use.
ingress-design-ingress-tlskeyfile-help: The file containing the private key for the specified TLS certificate.
ingress-design-generate-tls-files-label: Generate a TLS Certificate and Private Key
ingress-design-generate-tls-files-help: Whether to generate the TLS certificate and private key to use for the ingress TLS secret.
ingress-design-openssl-exe-file-path-hel: The full path to the OpenSSL executable to use for generating the TLS certificate and private key.
ingress-design-generate-tls-subject-labe: Subject to Use for the Generated TLS Certificate
ingress-design-generate-tls-subject-help: The Subject (e.g., /CN=www.mydomain.org) to use when generating TLS certificate. The format must be /type0=value0/type1=value1/type2=...
ingress-design-ingress-controller-chartv: Ingress Controller Helm Chart YAML Values (optional)
Modify or add your own Helm Chart Value for installing this ingress controller.
ingress-installer-checking-already-insta: Checking to see if the Ingress Controller {{ingressControllerName}} is already installed in Kubernetes namespace {{ingressControllerNamespace}}.
Failed to determine if the Ingress Controller {{ingressControllerName}} is already installed: {{error}}
ingress-installer-already-installed-erro: The Ingress Controller Provider: {{ingressProvider}} already installed as name: {{installedName}}, chart: {{chartName}}, namespace: {{namespace}}, status: {{status}}.
ingress-installer-create-ns-in-progress: Creating namespace for the ingress controller: {{ingressControllerNamespace}}
ingress-installer-create-ns-error-messag: Unable to install Ingress Controller because an error occurred while creating the namespace {{ingressControllerNamespace}}: {{error}}.
ingress-installer-add-repo-error-message: Unable to install Ingress Controller because an error occurred while adding Helm repo {{repoName}}: {{error}}.
ingress-installer-add-repo-in-progress: Updating Helm repo for Ingress Controller: {{ingressControllerName}}
ingress-installer-install-controller-err: Unable to install Ingress Controller: {{ingressControllerName}} because an error occurred: {{error}}.
ingress-installer-install-complete-messa: Ingress Controller {{ingressControllerName}} successfully installed to Kubernetes namespace {{ingressControllerNamespace}}.
ingress-installer-install-complete-noact: No Ingress Controller installed because install ingress controller is not enabled.
ingress-installer-install-failed-error-m: Unable to install ingress controller {{ingressControllerName}} to Kubernetes namespace {{ingressControllerNamespace}}: {{error}}.
ingress-installer-install-catch-all-erro: Ingress Controller installation failed with an unexpected error: {{error}}
ingress-installer-generate-tls-files-emp: Error in generating TLS files, subject is not set
ingress-installer-generate-tls-files-not: TLS private key or certificate file(s) specified {{files}} does not exist
ingress-installer-create-ingress-route-e: Error in creating ingress route {{ingressRoute}} reason: {{error}}
ingress-installer-create-ingress-route-d: Error in creating ingress route '{{ingressRoute}}', attribute: '{{attribute}}' is not set. This route will not be applied to the Kubernetes cluster when updating routes
ingress-installer-create-ingress-route-v: Error in creating ingress route '{{ingressRoute}}', attribute: '{{attribute}}' is not set when tlsEnabled. This route will not be applied to the Kubernetes cluster when updating routes

quickstart-dialog-stop-showing-quickstar: Stop showing this introduction at startup.
quickstart-page1-paragraph-1: Ready to get your WebLogic Server domain running in Kubernetes?
quickstart-page1-paragraph-2: This application will guide you through the process of creating a WebLogic Server domain in Kubernetes.
quickstart-page1-list-item-1: This is a native application with its own native application menus.
quickstart-page1-list-item-2: The application is broken out by sections: Model, Image, and Kubernetes. Use the left side navigation pane to switch between these sections.
quickstart-page1-list-item-3: Most sections provide a Design View and Code View page.  Design View is intended to simplify project configuration while Code View shows you the code.
quickstart-page1-list-item-4: Sections contain actions that perform work using external tools, like the WebLogic Kubernetes Toolkit (WebLogic Kubernetes Operator, WebLogic Deploy Tooling, or WebLogic Image Tool) and other container-related tools (docker/podman, kubectl, and Helm).
quickstart-page2-list-heading: The WKT UI application relies on Internet access for:
quickstart-page2-list-item-1: Downloading style sheets and fonts from the nearest Oracle CDN location.
quickstart-page2-list-item-2: Initializing certain section configuration fields' default values.
quickstart-page2-list-item-3: Checking GitHub for application updates and WKT tool installers.
quickstart-page2-list-item-4: Accessing Docker Hub, GitHub Container Registry, and any other remote Image registries the project specifies.
quickstart-page2-list-item-5: Accessing any remote Kubernetes cluster the project configuration specifies.
quickstart-page2-paragraph-1: As such, it is critical that you review the application preferences to make sure that the Proxy Configuration is correct for your environment.
quickstart-page2-paragraph-2: To access the application preferences, use the Preferences menu item, which is located in the File menu on Windows and Linux and in the application menu on MacOS.
quickstart-page2-paragraph-3: Should you have to change the Proxy Configuration, restart the application to make sure the application provides you all the help possible for the default values.
quickstart-page3-paragraph-1: The WKT UI application uses a project file to store user input.
quickstart-page3-list1-heading: Projects are created in two ways:
quickstart-page3-list1-item-1: Explicitly - By using the File menu's New Project menu item.
quickstart-page3-list1-item-2: Implicitly - By working in the application and performing an action that requires saving the project.
quickstart-page3-list2-heading: Important things to understand about the WKT UI project file:
quickstart-page3-list2-item-1: The file is in JSON format and must have a .wktproj file extension.
quickstart-page3-list2-item-2: Only fields with non-default values are saved in the file.
quickstart-page3-list2-item-3: The file only stores references to the WDT model-related files.  While the files are generally treated as part of the project, they are always stored in their WDT files.
quickstart-page3-list2-item-4: Credential fields are never stored in clear text.  They may be stored in the native OS credential store, encrypted in the project file, or not stored at all.
quickstart-page3-paragraph-2: The WKT UI application uses a one project per window paradigm.  If you try to open the same project file more than once, the application will simply bring the existing window into focus to prevent corruption of the file.
quickstart-page4-list1-heading: The Project Settings section defines key configuration values used throughout the application.  These include:
quickstart-page4-list1-item-2: Where to create the WebLogic Server domain relative to the image.
quickstart-page4-list1-item-3: What is the WebLogic Deploy Tooling target type that most closely matches your Kubernetes cluster.
quickstart-page4-list1-item-4: Which Java Home and Oracle Home directories to use for running the WKT tools.
quickstart-page4-list1-item-5: Which image build tool to use--Docker or podman.
quickstart-page4-list2-heading: Where you store the credentials affects sharing of the project file; the options are:
quickstart-page4-list2-item-1: Storing the credentials in the native OS credential store means that the credentials are only stored on the local machine.
quickstart-page4-list2-item-2: Storing the passphrase-encrypted credentials in the WKT project file means that you have to know the passphrase needed to decrypt the credentials.
quickstart-page4-list2-item-3: Not storing the credentials means that you need to re-enter credentials whenever the project file is opened.
quickstart-page4-list3-heading: Where you store the domain affects the life cycle of the domain; the options are:
quickstart-page4-list3-item-1: Storing the model of the domain in the image. WebLogic Kubernetes Operator creates the domain inside the containers started from the image.
quickstart-page4-list3-item-2: Storing the domain in the image. WebLogic Image Tool creates the domain while it is creating the image.
quickstart-page4-list3-item-3: Storing the domain in a Kubernetes persistent volume. The persistent volume and domain are created outside of this application and WebLogic Kubernetes Operator attaches the persistent volume to the domain's containers.
quickstart-page5-paragraph-1: WebLogic Deploy Tooling (WDT) defines a metadata model for describing a WebLogic Server domain.
quickstart-page5-list1-heading: This metadata model consists of three components:
quickstart-page5-list1-item-2: Variables - Defines a set of tokens to be used in the model and their values.
quickstart-page5-list1-item-3: Archive - Contains application-related and domain-related files and directories to be added to the domain.
quickstart-page5-list2-heading: The WKT UI application supports creating, discovering, importing, and editing WDT metadata models.
quickstart-page5-list2-item-1: Use the File menu's Add Model menu to discover a model from a domain or import existing model files.
quickstart-page5-list2-item-2: Use the Model section to create new or edit existing model-related files.
quickstart-page6-list-heading: The Model Code View page provides three panes that support viewing and editing the model-related files.
quickstart-page6-list-item-1: On the left side is the Model Editor that supports editing the model.
quickstart-page6-list-item-2: In the upper right is the Variable Editor that supports adding, removing, and updating variable names and their values.
quickstart-page6-list-item-3: In the lower right is the Archive Editor that supports adding, removing, and updating files and directories in the archive.
quickstart-page6-paragraph-1: In the action button bar, the Prepare Model button (or the Go menu item) optimizes the model for Kubernetes deployment.
quickstart-page6-paragraph-2: When running certain actions, such as Prepare Model, the collapsed Console panel automatically appears and displays the stdout and stderr streams.
quickstart-page7-paragraph-1: The WKT UI application supports creating a suitable Linux image for deploying your WebLogic Server-based domain.
quickstart-page7-list1-heading: When creating an image, you need to specify which:
quickstart-page7-list1-item-1: Image Tag to apply to the new image.
quickstart-page7-list1-item-2: Image Registry Push credentials to use to push the image to the registry specified in the Image Tag.
quickstart-page7-paragraph-2: The collapsible Advanced section provides access to other configuration that might be required in your environment.
quickstart-page7-list2-heading: Patching the Oracle Fusion Middleware installation is optional but strongly recommended. The application allows you to get:
quickstart-page7-list2-item-1: All Recommended Patches (which includes the latest PSU).
quickstart-page7-paragraph-3: All patches will be downloaded automatically using your Oracle Support user name and password.
quickstart-page8-paragraph-1: The WKT UI application requires the Kubernetes client tool kubectl to be properly configured to connect to your Kubernetes cluster.
quickstart-page8-list-heading: This section of the application helps you configure kubectl to be able to connect to your cluster:
quickstart-page8-list-item-1: Select the Kubernetes cluster provider type to see instructions for configuring kubectl for your cluster.
quickstart-page8-list-item-2: After configuring kubectl using the provided instructions, specify the correct values for the configuration properties in the section.
quickstart-page8-list-item-3: Use the Verify Connectivity action to make sure the application is able to connect to the cluster.
quickstart-page9-paragraph-1: When using the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator as the WDT target type, the following sections will be shown.
quickstart-page9-list1-item-3: Ingress Controller Section - Supports installing an ingress controller into your Kubernetes cluster and adding Ingress Routes to the already installed ingress controller.
quickstart-page9-list2-heading: This section makes it easy to install the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator into your Kubernetes cluster.
quickstart-page9-list2-item-1: Design view provides values for the various Kubernetes objects and Helm chart value overrides.
quickstart-page9-list2-item-2: Code view provides a shell script that shows how you can automate the installation.
quickstart-page9-list2-item-3: The Install Operator button (and Go menu item) performs the necessary actions to install the operator.
quickstart-page9-list3-heading: This section makes it easy to deploy the Kubernetes objects needed by the WebLogic Kubernetes Operator to deploy the domain and start the servers.
quickstart-page9-list3-item-1: Design view provides values for the various Kubernetes objects, including model variable override values and secret values.
quickstart-page9-list3-item-2: Code view provides a shell script that shows how you can automate the installation as well as the YAML resource definitions.
quickstart-page9-list3-item-3: The Deploy Domain button (and Go menu item) performs the necessary actions to deploy the Kubernetes objects required by the operator.
quickstart-page9-list3-item-4: The Get Domain Status button (and Go menu item) queries the Kubernetes cluster to determine the status of the last domain deployment action.
quickstart-page9-list4-heading: This section makes it easy to expose your domain's endpoint outside the cluster, as well as to install an ingress controller.
quickstart-page9-list4-item-1: Design view provides values for the various Kubernetes objects and Helm chart value overrides.
quickstart-page9-list4-item-2: Code view provides a shell script that shows how you can automate the installation as well as the YAML resource definitions.
quickstart-page9-list4-item-3: The Install Ingress Controller and Update Ingress Routing buttons (and Go menu items) perform the necessary actions to install the ingress controller and update routes on an existing ingress controller.
